LEO STEINER AND HARRY STEINER, RESPONDENTS, v. MORGAN MOTOR CAR COMPANY, INCORPORATED, A CORPORATION, APPELLANT. Submitted October 15, 1920 Decided March 23, 1927.

Before Justices Kalisch, Katzenbacii and Lloyd.

Por the appellant, Wolber £ Gilhooly. Por the respondent, Harry Sleiner. Per Curiam.

The Morgan Motor Car Company appeals from a judgment rendered against it in the Second District Court of Newark by the judge of that court sitting without a jury, for the amount of an insurance premium provided for in a lease of premises No. 1003 Broad street, Newark, between the Clinton Land and Improvement Company and the appellant, and which had been paid by the respondent.

The lease was dated April 11th, 1923, and ran for five years. It contained this clause: “And the party of the second part [appellant] further agrees that it will pay all water rates, insurance and taxes assessed upon the said property during the term.” Also that the agreement should bind the successors and assigns of the respective parties thereto.

*424At the time the lease was made the insurance was placed at $10,000, the premium on which was paid by appellant. This was renewed and likeAvise the premium paid. Early in 1926 Steiners, plaintiffs beloAv, bought the property from the Clinton Land and Improvement Company, which company (it is said by the respondent and acquiesced in by the appellant) assigned the lease to the Steiners, who, after investigation, demanded that the insurance be increased by $12,500. This being refused, the insurance was effected and the present action Avas instituted.

Payment Avas resisted on two grounds — ;-first, that the provision in the lease did not enure to the plaintiff, and second, that the amount already on the property was reasonably adequate.

The first ground we think is not well taken. The coarenant ran with the land, and enured to the benefit of the assignee of the reversion. 36 C. J. 169.

We also think the intention of the lease was to bind the parties in the event of its assignment either by the lessor or by the lessee, and that the provisions of the lease should-enure to the benefit of the assignee.

The second point made for reversal does not present a legal question. The obligation to pay the premium for insurance contemplated such insurance as might be found reasonably necessary to protect the property from loss by fire. What that amount might be was a disputed question of fact at the trial upon which there was variant proof, and the finding of the judge is not reviewable.

The judgment is affirmed.
